segment.source: Configure Authentication Methods (Windows 10)
segment.target: Configure Authentication Methods (Windows 10)

segment.source: Configure Authentication Methods
segment.target: Configure Authentication Methods

segment.source: Configure Authentication Methods
segment.target: Configure Authentication Methods

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: Windows Server 2016 Technical Preview
segment.target: Windows Server 2016 Technical Preview

segment.source: This procedure shows you how to configure the authentication methods that can be used by computers in an isolated domain or standalone isolated server zone.
segment.target: This procedure shows you how to configure the authentication methods that can be used by computers in an isolated domain or standalone isolated server zone.

segment.source: Note: If you follow the steps in the procedure in this topic, you alter the system-wide default settings.
segment.target: Note: If you follow the steps in the procedure in this topic, you alter the system-wide default settings.

segment.source: Any connection security rule can use these settings by specifying Default on the Authentication tab.
segment.target: Any connection security rule can use these settings by specifying Default on the Authentication tab.

segment.source: Administrative credentials
segment.target: Administrative credentials

segment.source: To complete these procedures, you must be a member of the Domain Administrators group, or otherwise be delegated permissions to modify the GPOs.
segment.target: To complete these procedures, you must be a member of the Domain Administrators group, or otherwise be delegated permissions to modify the GPOs.

segment.source: To configure authentication methods
segment.target: To configure authentication methods

segment.source: Open the Group Policy Management Console to Windows Firewall with Advanced Security.
segment.target: Open the Group Policy Management Console to Windows Firewall with Advanced Security.

segment.source: In the details pane on the main Windows Firewall with Advanced Security page, click Windows Firewall Properties.
segment.target: In the details pane on the main Windows Firewall with Advanced Security page, click Windows Firewall Properties.

segment.source: On the IPsec Settings tab, click Customize.
segment.target: On the IPsec Settings tab, click Customize.

segment.source: In the Authentication Method section, select the type of authentication that you want to use from among the following:
segment.target: In the Authentication Method section, select the type of authentication that you want to use from among the following:

segment.source: Default.
segment.target: Default.

segment.source: Selecting this option tells the computer to use the authentication method currently defined by the local administrator in Windows Firewall with Advanced Security or by Group Policy as the default.
segment.target: Selecting this option tells the computer to use the authentication method currently defined by the local administrator in Windows Firewall with Advanced Security or by Group Policy as the default.

segment.source: Computer and User (using Kerberos V5).
segment.target: Computer and User (using Kerberos V5).

segment.source: Selecting this option tells the computer to use and require authentication of both the computer and the currently logged-on user by using their domain credentials.
segment.target: Selecting this option tells the computer to use and require authentication of both the computer and the currently logged-on user by using their domain credentials.

segment.source: Computer (using Kerberos V5).
segment.target: Computer (using Kerberos V5).

segment.source: Selecting this option tells the computer to use and require authentication of the computer by using its domain credentials.
segment.target: Selecting this option tells the computer to use and require authentication of the computer by using its domain credentials.

segment.source: This option works with other computers that can use IKE v1, including earlier versions of Windows.
segment.target: This option works with other computers that can use IKE v1, including earlier versions of Windows.

segment.source: User (using Kerberos V5).
segment.target: User (using Kerberos V5).

segment.source: Selecting this option tells the computer to use and require authentication of the currently logged-on user by using his or her domain credentials.
segment.target: Selecting this option tells the computer to use and require authentication of the currently logged-on user by using his or her domain credentials.

segment.source: Computer certificate from this certification authority.
segment.target: Computer certificate from this certification authority.

segment.source: Selecting this option and entering the identification of a certification authority (CA) tells the computer to use and require authentication by using a certificate that is issued by the selected CA.
segment.target: Selecting this option and entering the identification of a certification authority (CA) tells the computer to use and require authentication by using a certificate that is issued by the selected CA.

segment.source: If you also select Accept only health certificates, then only certificates that include the system health authentication enhanced key usage (EKU) typically provided in a Network Access Protection (NAP) infrastructure can be used for this rule.
segment.target: If you also select Accept only health certificates, then only certificates that include the system health authentication enhanced key usage (EKU) typically provided in a Network Access Protection (NAP) infrastructure can be used for this rule.

segment.source: Advanced.
segment.target: Advanced.

segment.source: Click Customize to specify a custom combination of authentication methods required for your scenario.
segment.target: Click Customize to specify a custom combination of authentication methods required for your scenario.

segment.source: You can specify both a First authentication method and a Second authentication method.
segment.target: You can specify both a First authentication method and a Second authentication method.

segment.source: The first authentication method can be one of the following:
segment.target: The first authentication method can be one of the following:

segment.source: Computer (Kerberos V5).
segment.target: Computer (Kerberos V5).

segment.source: Selecting this option tells the computer to use and require authentication of the computer by using its domain credentials.
segment.target: Selecting this option tells the computer to use and require authentication of the computer by using its domain credentials.

segment.source: This option works with other computers that can use IKE v1, including earlier versions of Windows.
segment.target: This option works with other computers that can use IKE v1, including earlier versions of Windows.

segment.source: Computer (NTLMv2).
segment.target: Computer (NTLMv2).

segment.source: Selecting this option tells the computer to use and require authentication of the computer by using its domain credentials.
segment.target: Selecting this option tells the computer to use and require authentication of the computer by using its domain credentials.

segment.source: This option works only with other computers that can use AuthIP.
segment.target: This option works only with other computers that can use AuthIP.

segment.source: User-based authentication using Kerberos V5 is not supported by IKE v1.
segment.target: User-based authentication using Kerberos V5 is not supported by IKE v1.

segment.source: Computer certificate from this certification authority (CA).
segment.target: Computer certificate from this certification authority (CA).

segment.source: Selecting this option and entering the identification of a CA tells the computer to use and require authentication by using a certificate that is issued by that CA.
segment.target: Selecting this option and entering the identification of a CA tells the computer to use and require authentication by using a certificate that is issued by that CA.

segment.source: If you also select Accept only health certificates, then only certificates issued by a NAP server can be used.
segment.target: If you also select Accept only health certificates, then only certificates issued by a NAP server can be used.

segment.source: Preshared key (not recommended).
segment.target: Preshared key (not recommended).

segment.source: Selecting this method and entering a preshared key tells the computer to authenticate by exchanging the preshared keys.
segment.target: Selecting this method and entering a preshared key tells the computer to authenticate by exchanging the preshared keys.

segment.source: If they match, then the authentication succeeds.
segment.target: If they match, then the authentication succeeds.

segment.source: This method is not recommended, and is included only for backward compatibility and testing purposes.
segment.target: This method is not recommended, and is included only for backward compatibility and testing purposes.

segment.source: If you select First authentication is optional, then the connection can succeed even if the authentication attempt specified in this column fails.
segment.target: If you select First authentication is optional, then the connection can succeed even if the authentication attempt specified in this column fails.

segment.source: The second authentication method can be one of the following:
segment.target: The second authentication method can be one of the following:

segment.source: User (Kerberos V5).
segment.target: User (Kerberos V5).

segment.source: Selecting this option tells the computer to use and require authentication of the currently logged-on user by using his or her domain credentials.
segment.target: Selecting this option tells the computer to use and require authentication of the currently logged-on user by using his or her domain credentials.

segment.source: This authentication method works only with other computers that can use AuthIP.
segment.target: This authentication method works only with other computers that can use AuthIP.

segment.source: User-based authentication using Kerberos V5 is not supported by IKE v1.
segment.target: User-based authentication using Kerberos V5 is not supported by IKE v1.

segment.source: User (NTLMv2).
segment.target: User (NTLMv2).

segment.source: Selecting this option tells the computer to use and require authentication of the currently logged-on user by using his or her domain credentials, and uses the NTLMv2 protocol instead of Kerberos V5.
segment.target: Selecting this option tells the computer to use and require authentication of the currently logged-on user by using his or her domain credentials, and uses the NTLMv2 protocol instead of Kerberos V5.

segment.source: This authentication method works only with other computers that can use AuthIP.
segment.target: This authentication method works only with other computers that can use AuthIP.

segment.source: User-based authentication using Kerberos V5 is not supported by IKE v1.
segment.target: User-based authentication using Kerberos V5 is not supported by IKE v1.

segment.source: User health certificate from this certification authority (CA).
segment.target: User health certificate from this certification authority (CA).

segment.source: Selecting this option and entering the identification of a CA tells the computer to use and require user-based authentication by using a certificate that is issued by the specified CA.
segment.target: Selecting this option and entering the identification of a CA tells the computer to use and require user-based authentication by using a certificate that is issued by the specified CA.

segment.source: If you also select Enable certificate to account mapping, then the certificate can be associated with a user in Active Directory for purposes of granting or denying access to specified users or user groups.
segment.target: If you also select Enable certificate to account mapping, then the certificate can be associated with a user in Active Directory for purposes of granting or denying access to specified users or user groups.

segment.source: Computer health certificate from this certification authority (CA).
segment.target: Computer health certificate from this certification authority (CA).

segment.source: Selecting this option and entering the identification of a CA tells the computer to use and require authentication by using a certificate that is issued by the specified CA.
segment.target: Selecting this option and entering the identification of a CA tells the computer to use and require authentication by using a certificate that is issued by the specified CA.

segment.source: If you also select Accept only health certificates, then only certificates that include the system health authentication EKU typically provided in a NAP infrastructure can be used for this rule.
segment.target: If you also select Accept only health certificates, then only certificates that include the system health authentication EKU typically provided in a NAP infrastructure can be used for this rule.

segment.source: If you select Second authentication is optional, then the connection can succeed even if the authentication attempt specified in this column fails.
segment.target: If you select Second authentication is optional, then the connection can succeed even if the authentication attempt specified in this column fails.

segment.source: Important: Make sure that you do not select the check boxes to make both first and second authentication optional.
segment.target: Important: Make sure that you do not select the check boxes to make both first and second authentication optional.

segment.source: Doing so allows plaintext connections whenever authentication fails.
segment.target: Doing so allows plaintext connections whenever authentication fails.

segment.source: Click OK on each dialog box to save your changes and return to the Group Policy Management Editor.
segment.target: Click OK on each dialog box to save your changes and return to the Group Policy Management Editor.
